title: Modern humans Out of Africa – Southern coastal route
desc: Homo sapiens likely dispersed along the southern Arabian coastline into South Asia and onward to Southeast Asia/Australasia (~70–50 ka).
harvard_refs: Pagani, L. et al. (2015) Tracing the route of modern humans out of Africa using 225 genomes from Ethiopians and Egyptians. American Journal of Human Genetics, 96, 986–991.
López, S. (2016) Human dispersal out of Africa: a lasting debate. Nature Reviews Genetics, 17, 275–276.
Bae, C.J., Douka, K. and Petraglia, M.D. (2017) On the origin of modern humans: Asian perspectives. Science, 358, eaai9067.

title: Modern humans Out of Africa – Northern Levantine route
desc: A northern corridor via the Nile–Sinai–Levant into Southwest Asia and Eurasia; multiple pulses likely (~60–45 ka).
harvard_refs: Hershkovitz, I. et al. (2018) The earliest modern humans outside Africa. Science, 359, 456–459.
Kuhlwilm, M. and Fu, Q. (2022) Ancient human genomes suggest three ancestral populations for present-day Europeans. Current Opinion in Genetics & Development, 75, 101922.
Nielsen, R. et al. (2017) Tracing human history through ancient and modern genomes. Nature Reviews Genetics, 18, 395–408.

title: Modern human dispersal into Europe
desc: Modern humans entered Europe around 45 ka, encountering and eventually replacing Neanderthal populations. Genetic data show early admixture events.
harvard_refs: Fu, Q. et al. (2014) Genome sequence of a 45,000-year-old modern human from western Siberia. Nature, 514, 445–449.
Hajdinjak, M. et al. (2021) Initial Upper Palaeolithic humans in Europe had recent Neanderthal ancestry. Nature, 592, 253–257.

title: Peopling of the Americas
desc: Ancient genomes reveal migration from Siberia across Beringia into the Americas during the late Pleistocene.
harvard_refs: Raghavan, M. et al. (2014) Upper Palaeolithic Siberian genome reveals dual ancestry of Native Americans. Nature, 505, 87–91.
Moreno-Mayar, J.V. et al. (2018) Early human dispersals within the Americas. Science, 362, eaav2621.
